author: By Maria Cramer and Nate Schweber
title: Murder Victim’s Daughter Helps Clear Brooklyn Man Convicted in Killing
description: Prosecutors said they reviewed a 1982 case at the urging of the victim’s daughter, who became convinced the wrong man was convicted of her father’s killing.
content: In December 1982, four armed men burst into a bodega in Brooklyn serving as a front for marijuana dealing and ordered two men working inside to hand over drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Helen Marcus, Prolific Photographer of the Famous, Dies at 97
description: One of the few women at the top of her field in book and magazine publishing, she was also a champion of her fellow professionals.
content: Helen Marcus, a late-blooming photographer whose evocative black-and-white portraits of literary figures and film and television personalities graced book jackets and magazine covers for decades, died on Oct. 1 at her home in Manhattan. She was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick and Iyad Abuheweila
title: Many are killed near a Gaza hospital, its chief says, in a strike the Israelis say was aimed at Hamas.
description: The Israeli military said it targeted an ambulance “being used by a Hamas terrorist cell.” At the time, Palestinians said, a convoy of ambulances was preparing to take wounded people to the Gaza border.
content: An Israeli airstrike hit near the entrance of Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza City on Friday, killing multiple people, according to Gazan and Israeli officials, just as Palestinians said a convoy of ambulances was preparing to leave the hospital carrying wounded people to the Gaza border, to cross into Egypt for treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Flooding in Tuscany Leaves Six Dead
description: Storm Ciaran swept into Italy with torrential rains overnight, continuing its deadly push across Western Europe.
content: At least six people have died in Tuscany, Italy, amid widespread flooding, local officials said on Friday, after Storm Ciaran swept into the country with torrential rains overnight on a path of destruction across Western Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Seo
title: What to Know About Seasonal Depression
description: If you notice drastic shifts in your mood during certain times of the year, you could have seasonal affective disorder. Here are answers to your top questions about the condition.
content: The fall and winter months often signal the season of celebration and holidays. But for many, the darker, colder days herald another type of period: one of fatigue, lethargy and depression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Entous and Thomas Fuller
title: Blinken Urges ‘Pauses’ in Fighting to Deliver Aid for Gaza Civilians
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel appeared to rebuff the Biden administration’s request, saying that any cease-fire would be contingent on the release of Israeli hostages taken by Hamas.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, who traveled to Israel on Friday as the ground war against Hamas in Gaza escalated, urged protections for Palestinian noncombatants and “humanitarian pauses” in the fighting, even as he spoke of “solidarity” with Israel’s right to defend itself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 3, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 3, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about the knowledge of the deteriorating mental health of the man suspected of killing 18 people in a mass shooting in Maine misidentified the people who visited the him in May. It was his brother and sister, not his ex-wife and sister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
title: New Delhi Chokes as Annual Curse of Pollution Returns With a Vengeance
description: Schools shut down and residents were told to stay indoors as the government seems unable to avert an airborne calamity with multiple culprits that descends at the onset of winter.
content: Schools closed in New Delhi on Friday, while some diesel-burning vehicles were ordered off the roads and much of the city’s incessant construction was halted, as the authorities tried to mitigate the effects of a thick haze of pollution that has descended on India’s capital, a calamity that has come to be an annual blight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: Ligeti’s Fascinating Polyrhythm at the New York Phil
description: The conductor Susanna Mälkki led a program centered on Ligeti’s Piano Concerto, propelled by the soloist Pierre-Laurent Aimard.
content: On Thursday, the conductor Susanna Mälkki led the New York Philharmonic at David Geffen Hall in an unusually cohesive program built around the bizarro sound world of Ligeti’s Piano Concerto. It was part of the orchestra’s centennial celebrations of the composer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Former Pennsylvania Nurse Is Linked to 17 Nursing Home Deaths
description: Heather Pressdee, 41, confessed to trying to kill 19 patients with insulin. She had already been charged in the deaths of two others this year.
content: A former Pennsylvania nurse who had been accused of killing two patients with doses of insulin faces more murder charges and has confessed to trying to kill 19 additional people at several locations, the authorities said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rabea Eghbariah
title: An Unarmed Teen Was Shot During a Cease-Fire. Israel Was Never Held to Account.
description: The people of Gaza deserve to enjoy full civil rights, including the right to compensatory damages. Without those rights, what can we expect them to do with their pain?
content: On the afternoon of his 15th birthday, Attiya Nabaheen was walking home from his school in Gaza when an Israeli soldier shot him in the neck. It was November 2014, and Mr. Nabaheen was on his family’s land, situated about 500 meters from the militarized Green Line demarcating the Gaza Strip. In court proceedings, a lawyer representing the Israeli government claimed that Mr. Nabaheen was too close to the fence and didn’t heed warning shots before he was hit. Neither his age nor the fact that he was unarmed stopped the soldier from firing at the boy. The injury left Mr. Nabaheen permanently paralyzed and wheelchair bound for the rest of his life. This all happened during a cease-fire, a time of supposed peace, or status quo, in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: F.B.I. Raid of Adams Ally Brings Corruption Question to Mayor’s Doorstep
description: Mayor Eric Adams has faced ethics issues for years. A raid of his chief fund-raiser’s home poses a serious threat.
content: Even as Eric Adams completed his rise in New York City politics and became mayor, questions remained over ethical issues and his ties to people with troubling pasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Hear N.R.A.’s Free Speech Case Against New York Official
description: The case is the second one this term asking the justices to decide when government activity crosses the line to become coercion forbidden by the First Amendment.
content: The Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would decide whether a state official in New York violated the First Amendment by encouraging companies to stop doing business with the National Rifle Association after the 2018 school shooting in Parkland, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Less Pollution, More Global Warming
description: As we clean up the air, we also seem to making warming a bit worse.
content: Some good news: The air we breathe has been getting cleaner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Irjaliina Paavonpera
title: In the World’s Driest Desert, Ancient Wisdom Blooms Eternal
description: Burned out from life in New York, a photographer traveled to northern Chile to study the ancient wisdom of the Lickanantay, the area’s Indigenous people. Here’s what she saw.
content: I was seated with nine other artists in the middle of the Chilean desert, with volcanic Andean peaks ahead of me and the Cordillera de la Sal, or Salt Mountains, behind me. I squinted toward the early morning sun reaching over the peaks, feeling small as it began to light up the desert in every direction. Carlos, our host, had laid out a blanket on the warm sand and was now setting down a bottle of red wine, a bowl of coca leaves and four cups.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sofia Coppola’s Best Needle Drops
description: Hear songs that memorably accompanied scenes in “The Virgin Suicides,” “Lost in Translation,” “Priscilla” and more.
content: Few working filmmakers curate soundtracks with as much flair, style and intentionality as Sofia Coppola: Consider the melancholy dream-pop smeared through “Lost in Translation,” the new-wave tunes that give “Marie Antoinette” a playful modernity, or the eerie, weightless Air score that haunts the sleepy suburbs of “The Virgin Suicides.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: She Polled Gazans on Oct. 6. Here’s What She Found.
description: On the eve of the Oct. 7 attacks, Amaney Jamal asked Gazans what they thought about Hamas, their economic circumstances and their hopes for long-term peace.
content: The day before Hamas’s horrific attacks in Israel, the Arab Barometer, one of the leading polling operations in the Arab world, was finishing up a survey of public opinion in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in November
description: The final season of “The Crown” and the mini-series adaptation of a Pulitzer-winning novel highlight this month’s slate.
content: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of November’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: An Ode to the Women of Hip-Hop That Plays Like a Mixtape
description: On the genre’s 50th anniversary, “The Motherlode” honors contributions by the women, like Salt-N-Pepa, Roxanne Shanté and Megan Thee Stallion, who’ve made it what it is today.
content: Clover Hope’s “The Motherlode” pulses with beats of hip-hop history, from its hidden figures to its success stories, all told from a woman’s perspective. Borrowing its title from the West Coast rapper Yo-Yo’s 1991 debut album, “Make Way for the Motherlode,” the audiobook celebrates hip-hop’s 50th anniversary this year by correcting the male-dominated record, re-contextualizing the genre’s history in light of the contributions made by female artists from the 1970s to today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: A YouTube Gossip Spills a Secret of Her Own
description: For years, people have wondered who’s behind the popular Spill Sesh channel. On Friday, the person behind the account unmasked herself.
content: For the last five years, Spill Sesh, a popular YouTube channel, has covered the world of social media stars, providing detailed recaps and tart commentary on their scandals and beefs du jour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Emily Lang, Jen Poyant, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Sophia Lanman
title: Casey Goes to the White House + The Copyright Battle Over Artificial Intelligence + HatGPT
description: “It’s America, you can always sue.”
content: President Biden’s new executive order on artificial intelligence has a little bit of everything for everyone concerned about A.I. Casey takes us inside the White House as the order was signed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Noah Kahan’s Rootsy Rock Revival
description: Revisiting the rustic mainstream sound of the early 2010s, the Vermont singer-songwriter has broken through with “Stick Season.”
content: Noah Kahan’s song “Stick Season” currently sits at No. 43 on the Billboard Hot 100. On its own, that’s a moderately impressive feat. But it’s more remarkable because “Stick Season” is the title track of an album released just over a year ago. Via diligent touring and an instinctual grip on how to leverage TikTok, Kahan has squeezed a fan favorite so hard it became a hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Rare Trump Gun Control Measure Faces a Supreme Court Test
description: The justices agreed to decide whether the Trump administration had acted lawfully in banning bump stocks, the attachments that enable semiautomatic rifles to fire in sustained, rapid bursts.
content: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether the Trump administration had acted lawfully in banning bump stocks, the attachments that enable semiautomatic rifles to fire in sustained, rapid bursts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: David Kirke, Who Made the First Modern Bungee Jump, Dies at 78
description: An Oxford-educated prankster as colorful as he was daring, he accidentally helped invent a new extreme sport in the 1970s.
content: David Kirke, a flamboyant thrill-seeker who performed — and, more important, survived — what is widely acknowledged as the first modern bungee jump, died on Oct. 21 at his home in Oxford, England. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Can Humanities Survive the Budget Cuts?
description: After years of hand-wringing about their future, liberal arts departments now face the chopping block. At risk: French, German, American studies and women’s studies.
content: The state auditor of Mississippi recently released an eight-page report suggesting that the state should invest more in college degree programs that could “improve the value they provide to both taxpayers and graduates.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: A First Title for the Rangers, and a Thrill for the Former First Fan
description: Ownership of the Texas Rangers helped propel George W. Bush’s political career, and decades later, a friend says, baseball remains “part of who he is.”
content: It doesn’t come with a ring, but this week was still special for former First Fan George W. Bush. Nearly three decades after he sold the Texas Rangers, the team that propelled him into politics finally brought home its first World Series title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Headwind Cycling Race Called Off Over Too Much Wind
description: Storm Ciarán, which has battered Western Europe this week, proved too much for a quirky Dutch cycling competition.
content: One of the most eccentric sporting events on the Dutch calendar was canceled this week over safety concerns as Ciarán, a deadly storm, brought heavy rains and winds over 85 m.p.h. to parts of Western Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: What Is a Covenant Marriage?
description: A marriage contract that makes divorce difficult is a way for some couples to protect their partnerships. However, some experts believe that this type of union has both advantages and disadvantages.
content: Many states in America, depending on state-specific laws, allow “no-fault” divorces, in which either partner can end their marriage for any reason. But with a covenant marriage, there are stricter guidelines for ending a marriage. Revelations concerning Mike Johnson, the new speaker of the House, and his own covenant marriage have brought the unconventional commitment arrangement into the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a story of female revenge, a tale of a flying swordsman and a rip-roaring disaster flick.
content: Between “Gunpowder Milkshake,” “Baby Assassins,” and “Kill Boksoon,” the hit woman subgenre is bubbling with new subversive takes on the masculine hired gun motif. The Korean director Lee Chung-hyun’s “Ballerina” picks up those reins for a film about Okju (Jun Jong-seo), a retired bodyguard seeking to avenge the brutal murder of her dancer friend Minhee (Park Yu-rim) at the hands of a ruthless underworld predator (Kim Ji-hun).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Death, Disability: It’s All Fair Game for the Comic Daniel Sloss
description: The Scottish standup went viral for being the sole comic to go on the record in support of Russell Brand’s accusers. He’s made a career of finding humor in “things that we should not be laughing at.”
content: The Scottish comedian Daniel Sloss likes to flout conventional humor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: New Phase of Gateway Tunnel Project in Hudson River to Begin
description: Work on the long-delayed rail tunnel is set to speed up this month, as Senator Chuck Schumer announces an additional $3.8 billion in federal funding.
content: Construction of the long-delayed rail tunnel under the Hudson River is about to speed up, as the project gets an additional $3.8 billion in federal funding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin and Scott McIntyre
title: The Youngest Senior
description: Moving to Florida for early retirement, a native New Jerseyan in her 50s is finding her third act to be the most fun in a community where the average age is 79.
content: When residents at Sun City Center, a sprawling retirement community in West Central Florida, struggle with their electronics, many of them now know who to call on: Maria Hodge, one of their newest residents, and also one of their youngest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: In a Warming World, Clean Energy Stocks Fall While Oil Prospers
description: The market is focused on making money now and isn’t heeding urgent warnings about climate change, our columnist says.
content: Heat, drought, flood and famine. Evidence of climate change is all around us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Sheera Frenkel
title: In a Worldwide War of Words, Russia, China and Iran Back Hamas
description: Officials and researchers say the deluge of online propaganda and disinformation is larger than anything seen before.
content: The conflict between Israel and Hamas is fast becoming a world war online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a restored Disney classic, a wholesome family romp and an underdog dramedy.
content: In 1937, “Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs” captured the imaginations of children and adults, and set Disney on a path to creating endless classics, including “Fantasia” (1940), “The Lion King” (1994) and more. To celebrate the company’s 100th anniversary this year, Disney+ is streaming a 4K restoration of “Snow White.” While kids might be familiar with the story of the dark-haired princess, her mirror-loving evil stepmother and the seven dwarfs, it’s worth showing them the restored film version so they can absorb the tale in all its original glory (beautified by modern technology, of course).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simran Hans
title: How Should Assault Look Onscreen? It Doesn’t Need to Be Seen.
description: In new films, including “How to Have Sex,” female British directors emphasize the impact of sexual trauma, rather portraying the act itself.
content: When Molly Manning-Walker was a teenager, her favorite film was Gaspar Noé’s “Irreversible.” In a recent interview, she remembered being impressed by the film’s infamously brutal, nine-minute rape scene, and how “immersive” it was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Jeff Bezos Says He Is Leaving Seattle for Miami
description: The Amazon founder has lived in Seattle since 1994. He said he was returning to Miami, where he attended high school, in part to be closer to his parents.
content: Jeff Bezos, who founded Amazon out of his Seattle garage in 1994 and plowed billions of dollars into transforming the city into a tech boomtown, said on Thursday that he was leaving his home of three decades and moving to Miami.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Celebrates George Santos Sticking Around
description: Jimmy Kimmel was selfishly thrilled that the House voted to keep the New York representative in office, saying Santos “will live to scam another day.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Kingsbury
title: Opinion Today: Israel’s President on the Conflict With Hamas
description: Isaac Herzog’s guest essay is a valuable look at how Israel’s leadership views the war.
content: Our goal in Opinion is to publish a wide range of ideas, arguments and commentary that help readers see an issue or a debate in a new light, challenge their assumptions and grapple with the hardest problems societies face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: In ‘Köln Concert,’ Dancing Like Everyone’s Watching
description: Music by Keith Jarrett and Joni Mitchell set Trajal Harrell and his dancers in motion, but this pandemic-era piece feels mannered instead of spontaneous.
content: In 1975, the American jazz pianist Keith Jarrett played a solo concert in Cologne, Germany, improvising without a preset structure. The recording of that performance, “The Köln Concert,” became one of the best-selling solo jazz albums ever, its one-man-jam-band free exploration of sounds that you might associate with Rachmaninoff, gospel and country-folk proving as popular with fans of the Grateful Dead as with jazz aficionados.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David J. Bier
title: Biden Can’t Stop Immigration. Time to Embrace It.
description: No matter how cruel or restrictive his policies, they will never be enough to appease his critics.
content: When Joe Biden became president, he assumed a nearly impossible task: stopping migrants from crossing the U.S.-Mexico border amid a global displacement crisis. Despite his efforts, under his watch the number of people who crossed the border has risen sharply. Republicans have blamed the president, claiming that he has opened the borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: U.S. Job Growth Slows
description: Also, Eric Adams’s campaign faces corruption questions. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: U.S. employers added 150,000 jobs last month, according to data released today. The number was lower than experts had projected, and it signaled a cooling in the economy, but it remained not far off from the monthly job growth that the U.S. was experiencing before the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Two Ways of Looking at the West’s Population Dilemma
description: Old age and mass migration are the great forces of the 21st century.
content: In my Wednesday column, I wrote about the various unveilings and intimations of new alignments that have accompanied the Israel-Gaza crisis — with one reveal being the extent to which immigration is transforming European politics, forging a mass movement of Arab-Muslim protest that in turn may be driving European voters and even European elites toward the anti-immigration right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts and Chloë Ellingson
title: What it Takes to Wear the Sudoku Crown
description: Pens, pencils and a facility with numbers. Also helpful: earplugs, plushies, a water bottle, calming herbal oil and the occasional “wild bifurcation” (a.k.a. a wild guess).
content: On a mid-October Monday, shortly before 9 a.m., 179 elite puzzlers made their way into the ballroom of a Toronto hotel and found their allocated seats for the World Sudoku and Puzzle Championships. Valentin Miakinen of France positioned a plastic, pigeon-shaped hunting decoy at the front of his desk, for luck. Hwangrae Lee, from Korea, polished his pencil sharpener with a tissue. Quiet descended as proctors distributed booklets for Round 1: nine Sudoku puzzles, with a 45-minute time limit. Thomas Snyder, the general manager of the event, announced: “We begin in 5, 4, 3, 2, 1 — go!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Trudging Through Sobriety and Other Challenges, One Step at a Time
description: As Morgan Hartman and Phillip de Amezola supported each through personal health crises, their relationship and a “love plant” flourished.
content: In March 2018, Morgan Olivia Hartman, who was new to Alcoholics Anonymous, attended the Miami district annual A.A. banquet dinner. Phillip Xavier de Amezola, who had been sober for four years at the time, was also there, seated at another table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! We’re Booked on a Nile Cruise but Worry About Our Safety.
description: A Jewish couple about to go on a long-delayed $29,000 dream trip to Egypt and Jordan are afraid to travel because of the war in Gaza, but Viking says it’s safe.
content: After two pandemic-related delays, we were finally set to take a $34,309 Nile cruise with Viking, leaving Oct. 25 and including several days in Cairo and additional excursions to Jerusalem and Petra, in Jordan. But the war broke out, and the Middle East is very unstable. Viking canceled our excursion to Jerusalem, refunded that money and rebooked our flights for Oct. 29. But we don’t think Egypt or Jordan is particularly safe right now either, especially for Jews. We are older, and are heartsick at not seeing Jerusalem and terrified at the thought of being targeted as American Jewish tourists during this war. Viking still has $29,435 of our money. We only want a voucher to take the same trip in the future. Can you help? Joseph and Antonia, Oakland, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: The Presidential Fantasy Draft America Needs
description: Our 2024 options are terrible. Can we hope for more than Biden or Trump?
content: The polls are clear: Neither Joe Biden nor Donald Trump has the full confidence of American voters. But is Biden’s latest competition, Democratic Representative Dean Phillips of Minnesota, the answer to voters’ malaise? Or perhaps an independent candidate like Robert F. Kennedy Jr.?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: People and Penguins
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Mets Hire the Former N.Y.P.D. Commissioner Keechant Sewell
description: After abruptly resigning from the top job in the Police Department in June, Ms. Sewell will help lead security in Citi Field.
content: Keechant Sewell, the former New York City police commissioner, has been hired by the Mets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Don’t Underestimate the Power of a Compliment
description: Offering praise benefits everyone, experts say. Here’s how to do it like a pro.
content: A stranger gave me a compliment 10 years ago that I’ll never forget. I was at a diner in Brooklyn with my then 3-year-old and a few of her friends. I was making them laugh by acting silly — inserting two long French fries under my upper lip so I looked like a walrus, for example.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: The Woman Who Has Fought to Save L.A. History From Demolition
description: A conversation with Linda Dishman, the outgoing president of the Los Angeles Conservancy.
content: Some California cities are famed for their love of historic and cultural attractions. Los Angeles is not one of them — an unfair omission, I’ve always thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: With ‘Subject,’ Doc Stars Look Back
description: A talk with the directors Jennifer Tiexiera and Camilla Hall about their film that checks in on the subjects of high-profile documentaries.
content: Being a documentary subject can be a thankless kind of stardom, without much control over how your life story is told. In “Subject,” Jennifer Tiexiera and Camilla Hall went back to five famous documentaries and asked their stars about their experiences: “Hoop Dreams,” “The Staircase,” “Capturing the Friedmans,” “The Square” and “The Wolfpack.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Kyiv’s Exiled Biennial Is the Most Energizing Exhibition of the Year
description: The contemporary art show has spread beyond Ukraine’s borders and is now an eight-city European festival about war, democracy and solidarity.
content: Containment is a strategy that works only so long; the war will not stay put, the war will come to you. The Kyiv Biennial, a key fixture of contemporary art in Eastern Europe over the past decade, has opened its fifth edition on time and at full scale, but not (or not principally) at home. It has taken flight, spread beyond Ukraine’s borders. It has multiplied itself into a major European festival on war, democracy and the waning promise of solidarity. It has a scholar’s ambition but a slacker’s style; it spans a continent even as it anchors itself in Kyiv. It’s the most energizing exhibition of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jane Garrett, Book Editor With a Prizewinning Touch, Dies at 88
description: History books she shepherded over 44 years at Alfred A. Knopf won a raft of Pulitzers — seven in all — as well as Bancrofts, though one recipient set off a furious academic debate.
content: Jane Garrett, who as an editor at the Alfred A. Knopf publishing house guided seven books to Pulitzer Prizes for history but watched another book lose its prestigious Bancroft Prize over scholars’ criticism of the author’s research, died on Oct. 12 at her home in Middlebury, Vt. She was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Orange Cake, Orange Chicken and Gumbo (Which Is Also Kind of Orange)
description: Recipes that capture the flavors, and colors, of the season.
content: Good morning. Lisa Donovan is a pastry chef who happens to be an exquisite writer. “You cannot understand New Orleans, truly,” she wrote in “Our Lady of Perpetual Hunger,” her 2021 memoir,  “until someone who was raised by her, someone who loves her and is loved by her in return, takes you there.” Which is both a true statement and a wonderful sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Among American Chefs, the Israel-Hamas War Has Spread to Food
description: A recent petition signed by nearly 900 food professionals calling for a cease-fire raises, once again, questions of contested cuisines.
content: Theirs was an unlikely friendship.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Work From Home Isn’t Always Good
description: Responses to an essay about home and office work. Also: Mideast carnage; punishing lawyers; the Trump fraud trial; health care burnout; truth and comedy.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: Trump Misleads on Energy and Jobs at Houston Rally
description: A Biden electric Army tank mandate? A decimation of auto jobs? The G.O.P. front-runner used misleading and recycled claims to talk about energy and jobs.
content: At a campaign rally in Houston on Thursday that opened with former President Donald J. Trump erroneously referring to jailed Jan. 6 Capitol riot defendants as “hostages,” the Republican primary front-runner used a series of false and misleading claims to make his case for another term in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: At Paul Taylor, the Music Calls for a Dance. The Men Respond.
description: Lauren Lovette, the resident choreographer of Paul Taylor Dance Company, presents two new works as part of the group’s Lincoln Center season.
content: It’s not a race, but Lauren Lovette seems to be running, not walking, to create a body of work for the Paul Taylor Dance Company. Last year, after becoming Taylor’s resident choreographer, she presented two new works; this week, as part of the Taylor season at Lincoln Center, she added two more, including the world premiere of “Echo” on Thursday. It’s her finest offering yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: Not the Brightest Killer of the Flower Moon
description: Leonardo DiCaprio’s Ernest is unlike any Scorsese protagonist because, well, he’s dumb as rocks. And that changes the film in a fundamental way.
content: The demimondes depicted by the American master Martin Scorsese vary widely — his New York stories alone span three centuries — but they have one common requirement: It takes intelligence, of one kind or another, to navigate them. His protagonists are smart, street smart, shrewd, skillful or some combination of those qualities as a rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: What the Suburbs Did for Billy Joel and Bruce Springsteen
description: A new book by the author Jim Cullen explores the uncanny parallels between the careers of these two musicians, and how they were products of their time and place.
content: It was the 25th anniversary concert celebrating the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame at Madison Square Garden in 2009 when Bruce Springsteen bellowed to the crowd: “Are you ready for the bridge-and-tunnel summit meeting right here, right now? Because Long Island is about to meet New Jersey on the neutral ground of New York City!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Somewhat Guiltily, Ukrainians Miss Matthew Perry
description: Even as the war’s devastation rages on, Ukrainians have found space to mourn an actor who brought them comfort and laughter.
content: It was the middle of the night in Ukraine, and Natalia Sosnytska couldn’t sleep. So she opened the Instagram app on her phone — and saw that the actor Matthew Perry had died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
title: U.S. Faces Tricky Questions With African Trade Group
description: Tensions hung over a trade summit in Johannesburg after the Biden administration suspended four African countries that had belonged to a program aimed at promoting economic development.
content: As the United States seeks to deepen its relationships with African nations and counter the influence of rivals like Russia and China, it confronts a tricky question: How does it respond when countries do things that run afoul of Washington’s stated commitment to democracy and human rights?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Saleemul Huq, Bangladeshi Spearhead on Climate Change, Dies at 71
description: He pressed rich nations to compensate poorer ones for the disproportionate “loss and damage” they’ve endured because of greenhouse gas emissions.
content: Saleemul Huq, a Bangladeshi-British scientist who played a leading role in trying to get rich nations to compensate poorer ones for the damaging effects of climate change largely brought about by the developed world, died on Saturday in Dhaka, Bangladesh, the capital. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robbie Spencer
title: Finding the Right Match After Reconsidering a Swipe Left
description: Katherine Corrado was hesitant about dating someone in broadcast journalism. But after seeing Paul Gerke’s dating profile three years ago, she changed her mind.
content: When Katherine Mary Corrado and Paul Ryan Gerke first saw each other’s profiles on the dating app Bumble in September 2020, each found the other to be a breath of fresh air. There was just one problem for Ms. Corrado: Mr. Gerke was a “TV man,” so she swiped left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: As a Teen, She Loved Video Games. Now She’s Using A.I. to Try to Quash Malaria.
description: Rokhaya Diagne, a 25-year-old A.I. entrepreneur in Senegal, is part of a subset of Africa’s enormous youth population that is confident technology can solve the continent’s biggest problems.
content: When she was in her early teens, Rokhaya Diagne would retreat to her brother’s room, where she played online computer games for hours, day after day, until her mother finally got fed up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A Humanitarian Pause in Gaza
description: Civilians in Gaza have paid a grave price and urgently need relief.
content: Four weeks ago, Israel began its military campaign to defeat Hamas, in retaliation for the attack on Oct. 7 that killed more than 1,400 people, kidnapped some 240 others and destroyed a fundamental sense of security for all Israelis. Israel has a right to defend itself against this threat at its border, and the United States, its closest ally, has rightly pledged to stand by its side until that sense of security is restored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: How to Make the Most of the Morning Light
description: When the clocks fall back on Sunday, it’ll be dark much earlier. But if you embrace the extra early morning sunshine, your mood doesn’t have to suffer.
content: The dread sets in around 4 p.m., as the sun inches closer to the horizon and starts to wind down for the day. The end of Daylight Saving Time every fall can feel like something out of a Stephen King novel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Economists Ignored Inequality for Years. Now They Can’t Stop Talking About It.
description: A flurry of new books highlights broad disagreements over how to address the problem.
content: When the economist Angus Deaton moved to the United States in 1983, he was “in awe,” as he puts it in his new book, “Economics in America.” Born in Scotland and educated at the University of Cambridge, he remembers the swell of optimism he felt upon arriving at Princeton University. It was a “splendid place to work,” especially for someone who had been poor enough as a child to appreciate the measure of security provided by an “American salary.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: A Climate Change Success Story? Look at Hoboken.
description: This flood-prone city on the Hudson River has bundled water-absorbing infrastructure into benefits residents asked for, like parks and safer streets.
content: The city of Hoboken, N.J., once a marshy outcropping that the Lenape inhabited only seasonally, hugs the Hudson River. Three-quarters of it occupies a flood plain. It is, in other words, a water magnet. Some scientists have forecast that, with rising seas, a big chunk of Hoboken will be Atlantis by 2100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The World Series Didn’t Match the Very Best
description: The growing role of luck has made sports more exciting to watch, but at a cost.
content: This year’s World Series brought to mind the verse in Ecclesiastes about how the race is not to the swift nor the battle to the strong, but time and chance happen to them all. Swift and strong teams faltered in the playoffs, leaving the championship series to a couple of lucky unlikelies: the Arizona Diamondbacks and the Texas Rangers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Remembering Food’s Punk-Rock Moment and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
description: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Sends Biggest Drone Barrage in Weeks, Ukrainian Officials Say
description: Army officials and military analysts say it is part of a campaign to wear down and probe Ukrainian air defenses ahead of winter.
content: Russian forces targeted Ukraine overnight with their biggest drone attack in weeks, part of what Ukrainian officials and military analysts say appears to be a campaign to wear down and probe Ukrainian air defenses ahead of winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Open Enrollment Begins for Affordable Care Act Health Plans
description: Pandemic-era help with the monthly insurance premium costs continues through 2025.
content: The annual sign-up window for Affordable Care Act plans, which offer health insurance to millions of Americans who do not receive it through work, opened this week in most states. And the good news is that temporarily expanded federal help is expected to keep monthly costs manageable for many people next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: William Pelham Jr., Who Rethought How A.D.H.D. Is Treated, Dies at 75
description: A child psychologist, he argued that behavioral therapy had to come first in addressing attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, with drugs like Ritalin as a supplement.
content: William E. Pelham Jr., a child psychologist who challenged how his field approached attention deficit hyperactivity disorder in children, arguing for a therapy-based regimen that used drugs like Ritalin and Adderall as an optional supplement, died on Oct. 21 in Miami. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Fire at Drug Rehab Center in Iran Kills at Least 32, State Media Report
description: A local official reportedly said the center’s manager had been arrested, and he blamed overcrowding at the facility for the high toll.
content: At least 32 people were killed and 16 others injured when a fire tore through a drug rehabilitation center in northern Iran on Friday, state media reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Ian Stewart, Allison Benedikt, Jessica Metzger, Lisa Tobin and Dan Powell
title: The U.S. Says It Wants a Two-State Solution. What Do Its Arab Allies Want?
description: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war, with Lulu Garcia-Navarro and Times journalists on the ground.
content: U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken made a brief visit to Israel on Friday to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and other leaders. In addition to pushing for the safety of civilians in Gaza, Mr. Blinken emphasized the U.S. commitment to a two-state solution as the best path forward, and called on Arab partners to support that goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Sabbath’s Theater’ Review: John Turturro Embodies a Life and a Libido
description: Though a tour de force for its actors, an Off Broadway adaptation of Philip Roth’s willfully obscene 1995 novel is too faithful to its source.
content: John Turturro begins the New Group’s “Sabbath’s Theater” with his pants down. He ends it with his pants off. In between, he masturbates on his lover’s grave, wears a pair of pink panties on his head and lingers on an oncology ward discussing outré sexual practices. This suggests a work meant to shock or at the very least goose the viewer. But excepting the performances of Turturro and Elizabeth Marvel as Sabbath’s wives and lovers, the show, for all its full-frontal nudity, is strangely inert. Flaccid? Sure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: As Cars Have Grown Bigger, Parking Spaces Might, Too
description: Australians are grumbling about a recent invasion of American-style giant pickup trucks. But even before that, vehicle sizes were increasing.
content: Massive American-style pickup trucks are having a surge of popularity in Australia, to the annoyance of some drivers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: A ‘Professional Crush’ Turns Romantic
description: When Leah Wong met Dennis Fan, she was inspired by his passion for his work. His advice helped shape a future they are building together.
content: When Leah Wong and Dennis Fan first met at a happy hour at the National Asian Pacific American Bar Association Convention in Austin, Texas, in November 2019, there was a spark. And it was purely professional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: 4 Shows to Catch at the New York Comedy Festival
description: It’s a sprawling, citywide event, but our expert has a strategy and some suggestions for you.
content: The offerings at the annual New York Comedy Festival, which takes place across the city Friday through Nov. 12, are vast enough to be overwhelming. Stars like Bill Burr, Anthony Jeselnik, Nicole Byer and Michelle Wolf stand out. Then there are New York club veterans like Sam Morril and Matteo Lane moving up a class by playing big rooms at Madison Square Garden and Carnegie Hall. And if you study the schedule, you can also find many smaller acts. The best way to enjoy the festival is by seeing some familiar names, but also taking a few shots in the dark on comics you don’t know or only a little. That’s the fun part for me. If you’re looking for a start, here are a few promising options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Olivia Rodrigo’s Haunting ‘Hunger Games’ Tune, and 9 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Megan Thee Stallion, Torres, Mount Kimbie and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L., on Lookout for Growth, Finds Open Arms in Germany
description: Football was introduced to the country by U.S. soldiers after World War II, but interests soared when the N.F.L. played its first regular-season game there last year.
content: About 60 hardcore fans of the National Football League piled into the party space at Der Player, a fancy eatery, on a chilly evening in Hamburg, Germany, last month. Wearing jerseys and hoodies of teams like the Chicago Bears, the Kansas City Chiefs and the Las Vegas Raiders, they grabbed seats to watch a taping of “Prime Time Football Live,” which attracts thousands of viewers on YouTube.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Some Psychiatrists Have Started Prescribing Ozempic
description: Doctors say the diabetes medication, and drugs like it, could counteract the weight patients gain on antipsychotics and antidepressants.
content: It was Joanna Acevedo’s psychiatrist who first raised the idea of a weight-loss drug. Since 2018, Ms. Acevedo has relied on antipsychotic medications to manage her bipolar disorder. The drugs kept her paranoia at bay — really, they kept her alive, she said. They also led her to gain 70 pounds. By age 26, she had become prediabetic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: In High-Stakes Speech, Hezbollah’s Leader Stops Short of Call to Expand Hamas War
description: In his first public comments since the war in Gaza began, Hassan Nasrallah said his powerful Lebanese militia had bogged down Israeli forces to help Hamas.
content: Since the war in Gaza began after Hamas’s surprise attack on Israel on Oct. 7, people across the Middle East have feared it could set off a second war between Israel and Hezbollah, the powerful Lebanese militia, and ignite a broader regional conflagration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: A Fast, Foolproof Carbonara for Orzo Lovers
description: Combining the last-minute simplicity of a carbonara, and the rich-tasting comfort of a long-cooked risotto, this dish is the perfect cold-weather weeknight dinner.
content: The Italian carbonara police don’t want you to put ham in your spaghetti carbonara; they’ve made that clear. And don’t even think about splashing in cream or grating over Parmesan instead of pecorino.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Job Growth Slows, Sowing a Mix of Concern and Calm
description: U.S. employers added 150,000 workers in October, falling short of expectations, but the labor market retains spark nearly three years into a recovery.
content: The labor market has been relentlessly hot since the U.S. economy began to recover from the shock of the pandemic. But there are signs of cooling as the holidays approach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Friday Briefing
description: Israeli troops enter Gaza City.
content: Israeli soldiers have encircled Gaza City, the Israeli military said yesterday, waging “face-to-face battles” with Hamas as they push forward with what officials have predicted will be a long and bloody ground invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Shakespeare’s First Folio Turns 400
description: Sarah Lyall talks to Adrian Edwards, head of the Printed Heritage Collections at the British Library, about the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare’s First Folio.
content: In 1623, seven years after William Shakespeare died, two of his friends and fellow actors led an effort to publish a single volume containing 36 of the plays he had written, half of which had never been officially published before. Now known as the First Folio, that volume has become a lodestone of Shakespeare scholarship over the centuries, offering the most definitive versions of his work along with clues to his process and plenty of disputes about authorship and intention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: Netflix DVDs, Scorsese and Me
description: For a singular marathon of the filmmaker’s work, the discs were vital amid lockdown. A look at the newly shuttered service and how other renters used it.
content: The death notice arrived softly one Tuesday in April, to an email alert that chimed like a chapel bell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Judge Rules in Family Dispute Over Rockwells Long Hung at White House
description: Relatives of Franklin Delano Roosevelt’s press secretary went to federal court to resolve a disagreement over who owned Norman Rockwell drawings valued at $8 million.
content: A federal judge has made a decision in a dispute between relatives of Franklin D. Roosevelt’s press secretary over ownership of four Norman Rockwell drawings that hung for decades in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: New York City Is Getting Tired of Mayor Adams’s Scandals
description: The drama and foolishness involving the mayor’s inner circle doesn’t serve the city well and is the last thing New York needs right now.
content: No sooner did Mayor Eric Adams of New York land in Washington, D.C., on city business Thursday than he had to turn right back around to take care of his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Sam Bankman-Fried Was a Grown Up Criminal, Not an Impulsive Man-Child
description: Investors bought into the perception of the FTX founder as an unkempt boy genius. The jury didn’t buy it.
content: Sam Bankman-Fried, crypto’s Icarus, was convicted of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy on Thursday night after a trial that generated 10 million pages of documents and only a few hours of jury deliberation. As ever, it is perhaps best to start from the very beginning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: A $75 Million Sale at 220 Central Park South Is One of the Year’s Biggest
description: The full-floor apartment was sold to a buyer who already owns a condo in the building. Another property went for $66 million, and still others for $50 million or more.
content: A flurry of big sales closed in New York City during October, including one of the year’s priciest, a full-floor aerie at 220 Central Park South purchased in a private deal for $75 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Silicon Valley Shrugs Off Sam Bankman-Fried’s Trial
description: Tech investors lauded Mr. Bankman-Fried and helped fund his FTX crypto exchange. The tech industry has since done what it does best: move on.
content: In the four weeks that Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, was on trial on fraud charges, the tech industry:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Revisiting the Gaza Hospital Explosion
description: We look at the evidence for who is responsible.
content: Last month, a few days after the explosion at Al-Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City, I walked you through the debate over who was responsible. At the time, there wasn’t much evidence that outsiders could assess on their own. The dispute revolved around competing claims from Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Hosts Leaders of South American Nations for an Economic Summit
description: One goal is to help bolster economies of countries across the region so they can better absorb the millions of migrants who are fleeing poverty, political instability and natural disasters.
content: President Biden hosted officials from 11 countries in the Western Hemisphere on Friday for a meeting intended in part to address the historic flow of migrants in the region by bolstering the economies of Mexico, Ecuador, Panama and other countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: sumptuous
description: This word has appeared in 152 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word sumptuous has appeared in 152 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 16 in “Withstanding the Passage of Time, but Not the Shaking of the Earth” by Vivian Yee and Aida Alami:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Is Fluminense the Team of the Future?
description: A soccer revolution started with a text message, but the broader game wants proof. A win in the Copa Libertadores final on Saturday might provide it.
content: The story starts with a message. Everything that has followed and everything that might yet — the glory and the acclaim, the opportunity and the revolution — has unspooled from a simple text. Everyone involved can agree on that. What is not entirely clear, though, is precisely which message was the one that counted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Light
title: Rock ’n’ Soul: The Amazing Story of Sly & the Family Stone
description: At the age of 80, Sly Stone has finally produced his memoir, and it gives a strong sense of this giant’s voice and sensibility.
content: It is difficult to convey just how astoundingly unlikely it is that this book exists. Sly Stone is one of pop music’s truest geniuses and greatest mysteries, who essentially disappeared four decades ago in a cloud of drugs and legal problems after recording several albums’ worth of incomparable, visionary songs. Fleeting, baffling, blink-and-you-miss-him appearances at his 1993 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame induction and a 2006 Grammy tribute only served as reminders that he was still alive and still not well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Mount Sinai Seeks to Close One of Lower Manhattan’s Last Hospitals
description: The private hospital system asked state regulators to close Mount Sinai Beth Israel, which serves a swath of Lower Manhattan that has already lost several major medical institutions.
content: One of the last remaining hospitals serving Lower Manhattan may well close next year, despite opposition from local officials and health activists who say the lessons of the pandemic are going unheeded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Tony Cenicola
title: Electric Planes, Once a Fantasy, Start to Take to the Skies
description: How a small plane’s 16-day trip from Vermont to Florida might foreshadow a new era of battery-powered air travel long considered implausible.
content: Chris Caputo stood on the tarmac at Burlington International Airport in Vermont in early October and looked to the clouds in the distance. He had piloted military and commercial aircraft over a long career, racking up thousands of flight hours, but the trip he was about to take would be very different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Wild Rise and Abrupt Crash
description: The crypto king gambled that his trading platform would make him a benevolent trillionaire. But after a fraud conviction, all bets are off.
content: There comes a moment in the development of a new technology when the hype is so common it passes for common sense. Lawyers, accountants and regulators are nowhere to be found. Investors insist entrepreneurs take their money. The world trembles on the brink of change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
title: Japan and Philippines, Wary of China, Look to Expand Military Ties
description: An agreement, driven by the shared view that Beijing increasingly poses a threat to the region, would give Tokyo access to bases and make it easier to conduct joint drills.
content: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan said on Friday that his country would start formal talks with the Philippines to allow the deployment of Japanese troops to the Southeast Asian country, further strengthening ties between two countries that have embraced each other as bulwarks against China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian M. Rosenthal and Eliza Shapiro
title: New York Tightens Special Education Rules, Aiming to Reduce Fraud
description: New York City’s public schools will step up oversight of funding for private tutoring and other services after a New York Times investigation revealed questionable billing.
content: Over the last decade, New York City has faced a startling rise in requests to pay for special education services for private school students, a deluge that has cost billions of dollars and raised concerns about fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Mint, One of the First Budgeting Apps, Is Shutting Down
description: Intuit, which acquired Mint in 2009, is encouraging users to switch to Credit Karma, its money management and credit score service.
content: Mint, one of the earliest and most popular personal finance apps, is shutting down, and its owner, Intuit, is encouraging users to switch to Credit Karma, its platform that offers free credit scores and helps users track their money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: On TikTok, Gen Z Beatles Fans Share Thoughts on ‘Now and Then’
description: “Can’t believe it’s 2023 and I get the joy of hearing a new Beatles song for the first time ever,” a 23-year-old says in a video post.
content: Eloise Smith, 23, posted a reaction video on TikTok immediately after listening to “Now and Then,” the Beatles song released on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Otto Klemperer’s Conducting Still Stuns, 50 Years After His Death
description: Recording collections reveal the talents of an essential 20th-century musician who lived through mental illness, Nazism and other tribulations.
content: There is a touching documentary about Otto Klemperer, that steadfast titan of conducting who died 50 years ago, by the filmmaker Philo Bregstein. Watch it for long enough, and a rather surprising face appears — surprising, at least, if you think of Klemperer as he is so often imagined, as only the last in a venerable line of German musicians, and not as the architect of something new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Will Reid, Rikki Novetsky, Rob Szypko, Paige Cowett, Lisa Chow, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Sophia Lanman and Chris Wood
description: How the events of that fateful year shaped the Israeli-Palestinian conflict for decades to come.
content: As the Israeli-Palestinian conflict enters its darkest chapter in decades, both sides are evoking the same foundational moment in their past: the events of 1948.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein and Jonah Markowitz
title: Why Run the New York City Marathon When You Can Drive It?
description: You’re not going to catch the elite runners. But if you can get over the traffic, the scenery is terrific. And the doughnuts aren’t bad either.
content: An eighteen-wheeler sat motionless at the intersection of 26th Street and Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn, completely blocking traffic in all directions. As motorists blasted their horns in an orchestra of rage, the bewildered truck driver hopped down from the cab and began yelling — in a distinctly out-of-town drawl — at the pileup of cars behind him on 26th, demanding they back the heck up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: New York Times Writer Resigns After Signing Letter Protesting the Israel-Gaza War
description: The writer, Jazmine Hughes, who has won awards for her work, had signed another letter of protest this year.
content: Jazmine Hughes, an award-winning New York Times Magazine staff writer, resigned from the publication on Friday after she violated the newsroom’s policies by signing a letter that voiced support for Palestinians and protested Israel’s siege in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Manhattan Jury Clears Ex-Prosecutor of Rape and Assault Charges
description: Adam Foss, a prominent criminal justice reform advocate, had been accused of assaulting a woman in a Midtown hotel room in 2017.
content: A former Boston prosecutor who was charged with rape and sexual abuse in Manhattan last year was acquitted of all charges by a jury on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walker Mimms
title: The Original Birders Gave Photography a Run for its Money
description: Two art books revisit 19th-century illustrations by John James Audubon and Elizabeth Gould.
content: As the National Audubon Society recovers from a referendum to change its name in light of the fact that America’s founding birder was a slave owner (the name stayed), a luxe reissue of John James Audubon’s magnum opus, BIRDS OF AMERICA (Abbeville, $195), proves the man’s artistry itself unimpeachable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Ronen Bergman
title: As Gaza War Enters New Phase, Israel Faces Pressure Over Civilian Deaths
description: Fears are rising that the conflict could spread to the occupied West Bank, where tensions are soaring among Palestinians angered over deadly Israeli airstrikes in Gaza.
content: Nearly a week after Israeli tanks and troops poured into Gaza, Israeli military officials say they have made steady gains against Hamas. But the ground operation, which now encircles Gaza City, is entering an acutely perilous phase, with Israelis troops advancing in an urban landscape that is honeycombed with tunnels and home to many Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Mourns With Lewiston After Mass Shooting: ‘You’re Not Alone’
description: President Biden met with the families of those killed or injured during last month’s rampage in Maine, which killed 18 people.
content: Since taking office, President Biden has traveled a grim path through American communities desperately grieving in the wake of mass shootings: Uvalde, Texas; Monterey Park, Calif.; Buffalo; Atlanta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Yancey
title: 3 New Middle Grade Science Fiction Novels Disturb and Delight
description: Jeanne DuPrau’s “Project F,” Patricia Forde’s “The Girl Who Fell to Earth” and Donna Barba Higuera’s “Alebrijes” answer the question, Could this be the beginning of the end?
content: Worldwide flooding. Massive Canadian wildfires. Monster hurricanes. Record-breaking heat waves. Sauna-level sea temperatures. The loss of billions of tons of Arctic and glacial ice. The existential question of the summer was, Could this be the beginning of the end? Three new speculative novels for young readers answer yes, with varying degrees of resignation and sorrow, bitterness and hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Jewish Viewers Find a Refuge in Fox News
description: The network’s unflinching support for Israel in its fight against Hamas has put the conservative network in the good graces of many Jews who see other coverage of Israel as biased.
content: Ross Abramson, a software engineer and recent New York University graduate, had a fairly conventional news diet until recently. He regularly checked his phone for The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal. And as a Jew with an interest in Israel, he would browse a handful of outlets like The Times of Israel.

author: By Clay Risen
title: Jeffrey A. Bader, Who Helped Steer Obama’s ‘Pivot’ to Asia, Dies at 78
description: A veteran China expert, he advised Presidents Clinton and Obama as they navigated the complexities of Beijing’s rise to global power.
content: Jeffrey A. Bader, one of the country’s leading experts on China and an architect of President Barack Obama’s so-called pivot to the Pacific during his first administration, died on Oct. 22 in Los Angeles. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Magic in the First Five Minutes. Love Within 15.
description: After their first date, Banks Clark slipped a note into Jackie Patmore’s purse. “You have changed everything,” it read.
content: Jacqueline Marie Patmore and Banks Thomas Clark barely touched their appetizers — deviled eggs, brussels sprouts, onion rings and jalapeño poppers — during their first date one rainy evening in October 2021 at Freebird Kitchen and Bar in White Plains, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘I Need That’ Review: It’s Always Messy in New Jersey
description: Danny DeVito returns to Broadway in a Theresa Rebeck comedy about a lonely old man lost in a houseful of junk.
content: Even before the lights dim at the start of “I Need That,” the new Theresa Rebeck play at the American Airlines Theater, the show curtain and what’s in front of it offer plenty of exposition. The curtain is painted to depict the street grid of a neat New Jersey town, with neat houses on neat lots. But, uh-oh, creeping out from beneath it, on the floor of the stage, are boxes and bins overflowing with junk: ancient copies of Popular Science, bruised holiday decorations, stacks of old clothes, a sad single sneaker.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jurors in Trump Defamation Trial to Go Unnamed for Their Own Protection
description: A federal judge overseeing the case filed by the writer E. Jean Carroll said that the former president had not abided by gag orders in other cases, and that could lead to harassment.
content: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled Friday that the jury in a forthcoming defamation trial against Donald J. Trump will be kept anonymous for the jurors’ own protection, citing the potential for harassment by the former president’s supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

content: When Jill Ellis stepped back from coaching after winning back-to-back World Cups in 2015 and 2019 with the U.S. women’s team, her wife, Betsy Stephenson, thought the number of soccer matches watched in their house might decrease.

title: A Giant Leap for the Leap Second. Is Humankind Ready?

content: Later this month, delegations from around the world will head to a conference in Dubai to discuss international treaties involving radio frequencies, satellite coordination and other tricky technical issues. These include the nagging problem of the clocks.

title: Ohio Lawsuit Punches Back in Battle Over How to Teach Reading

content: When Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio set out to overhaul reading instruction in his state this year, it seemed like another sign that the decades-long debate over how to teach reading had come to a tipping point.

title: A Marriage Problem That Can’t Be Solved
description: My husband and I haven’t spoken in more than a year. It can’t go on like this, but it will.
content: My husband and I are going through a really difficult time in our marriage, and there doesn’t seem to be a lot of advice for how to proceed. We haven’t spoken in more than a year. When the children ask where he is, I don’t know what to say. I have had to take over all the household tasks, plus a lot of legal and financial paperwork. I’ve had a lot of time to reflect on all the things I’ve done wrong, but I can’t apologize.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Republican National Committee Announces Tougher Criteria for Fourth Debate
description: Over the objections of its front-runner, the party has set a date for a fourth primary debate that will take place in Tuscaloosa, Ala., next month.
content: The Republican National Committee has set a date for the fourth debate of the 2024 primaries — over the objection of the party’s front-runner, Donald J. Trump — and incrementally ratcheted up the criteria to make the stage, according to a memo sent to campaigns on Friday.

content: In 1984, Leonel Martínez of Venezuela competed in the trap shooting event at the Los Angeles Olympic Games. He finished tied for 41st.

title: Appeals Court Temporarily Frees Trump From Gag Order in Election Case

content: An appeals court in Washington on Friday paused the gag order imposed on former President Donald J. Trump in the federal case accusing him of seeking to overturn the 2020 election, temporarily freeing him to go back to attacking the prosecutors and witnesses involved in the proceeding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel Diamond, Talia Dror and Jillian Lederman
title: What Is Happening on College Campuses Is Not Free Speech
description: Not only are harassment and intimidation not protected by the First Amendment, but they fly in the face of the purpose of a university.
content: Since the Hamas terrorist attacks on Oct. 7, campus life in the United States has imploded into a daily trial of intimidation and insult for Jewish students. A hostile environment that began with statements from pro-Palestinian student organizations justifying terrorism has now rapidly spiraled into death threats and physical attacks, leaving Jewish students alarmed and vulnerable.

title: Laufey’s Old-Time Pop Is Smooth. Its Relationship to Jazz Is Spikier.
description: The 24-year-old multi-instrumentalist found fame on TikTok with her nostalgic songs. But her dedication to her followers may be holding her music back.
content: About 20 minutes into her set at Town Hall on Wednesday night — the first of two sold-out shows at the Midtown Manhattan theater — the nostalgic TikTok star Laufey put down her hollow-body electric guitar. With her hands free, she started singing “Dreamer,” the barbershop-pop tune that opens her second album, “Bewitched.” As she moved across the stage, she struck a new pose for each line: bending forward at the waist, as if to share a morsel of gossip; leg straight, hip bent; head turned sideways, as if mid-sigh.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: David Balton and Jane Stewart build a puzzle in an orderly fashion.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage begins in space and ends in the recesses of our minds, which is no mean feat in some 35 words. It’s an excerpt from a 1987 book by Jean Aitchison, a linguist, called “Words in the Mind: An Introduction to the Mental Lexicon.” In it, Ms. Aitchison differentiates between syntax, which organizes how we link words and structures our communication, like mortar, and vocabulary, which builds up in our memory block by block, like bricks.

content: We often measure the tragedy of war in the suffering of children, but rarely do we hear from them. Two years ago, filmmakers asked children in Gaza, where nearly half the population is under 18, a seemingly simple question: What is your dream? The video above reveals their answers which, in light of the violence that has embroiled the region in recent weeks, are all the more poignant.
